title: Western Australian Party
text: The Western Australian Party (WAP) was a short-lived <a href="Australia">Australia</a>n political party that operated in 1906. It was intended as a <a href="Liberalism">liberal</a> party to protect the rights of <a href="Western%20Australia">Western Australia</a>ns and to oppose the increasingly successful <a href="Australian%20Labor%20Party%20%28Western%20Australian%20Branch%29">Labour Party</a>, and drew its supporters from the <a href="Protectionist%20Party">Protectionist Party</a> and the <a href="Anti-Socialist%20Party">Anti-Socialist Party</a>. <a href="John%20Forrest">John Forrest</a>, a minister in <a href="Alfred%20Deakin">Alfred Deakin</a>'s government, accepted the leadership of the party. Candidates were endorsed for all electorates in the <a href="1906%20Australian%20federal%20election">1906 federal election</a>, including Forrest, but by the time of the election enthusiasm for the venture had diffused. The party elected Forrest in <a href="Division%20of%20Swan">Swan</a> and <a href="William%20Hedges%20%28Australian%20politician%29">William Hedges</a> in <a href="Division%20of%20Fremantle">Fremantle</a>. In practice they sat as <a href="independent%20%28politician%29">independents</a> and joined the <a href="Commonwealth%20Liberal%20Party">Commonwealth Liberal Party</a> when it formed.
